SUMMARY: REQUIRED | OPTIONAL DETAIL: ELEMENT

com.rexsl.core
Annotation Type Stylesheet

@Documented
@Retention(value=RUNTIME)
@Target(value=TYPE)
public @interface Stylesheet

Annotation for a class, to indicate which XSL stylesheet to attach to it during XML-to-XHTML transformation.

For example, this is your JAX-RS resource, returning JAXB-annotated object on HTTP /front request: 

 import javax.ws.rs.GET;
 import javax.ws.rs.Path;
 import javax.ws.rs.Produces;
 import javax.ws.rs.core.MediaType;
 @Path("/front")
 public final class FrontEndResource {
  @GET
  @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_XML)
  public Front front() {
   return new Front();
  }
 }

Because of Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_XML) annotation JAX-RS knows that the object returned has to be converted to XML (it's done by Marshaller instantiated by XslResolver). Let's say, this is the object: 

 import javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlElement;
 import javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlRootElement;
 @XmlRootElement(name = "front")
 public final class Front {
  @XmlElement
  public String title() {
   return "hello, world!";
  }
 }

The XML generated by JAXB will look like this: 

 <?xml version="1.0"?>
 <?xml-stylesheet href="/xsl/Front.xsl" type="text/xsl"?>
 <front>
  <title>hello, world!</title>
 </front>

Then, this XML is sent to the browser and it converts it to XHTML using provided stylesheet: /xsl/Front.xsl. This stylesheet should be available in webapp directory. The name of stylesheet is constructed from a simple name of the class Front.

What if we want to use another XSL stylesheet for this class? Then we need &#64;Stylesheet annotation: 

 import javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlElement;
 import javax.xml.bind.annotation.XmlRootElement;
 @XmlRootElement(name = "front")
 @Stylesheet("http://example.com/custom-stylesheet.xsl")
 public final class Front {
  @XmlElement
  public String title() {
   return "hello, world!";
  }
 }

Now the output XML will look like: 

 <?xml version="1.0"?>
 <?xml-stylesheet href="http://example.com/custom-stylesheet.xsl"
   type="text/xsl"?>
 <front>
  <title>hello, world!</title>
 </front>
